resources.string:
Supporting Women and Girls in Pakistan Scaling Up
 Empowerment and Care Strategies to Address Health and Survival
 Centre of Excellence Women & Child Health
 Aga Khan University, Karachi, Pakistan
Children with _________________ on the IMNCI chart usually need urgent referral to hospital.
_________________is the exception for severe classification or severe disease where referral to the hospital is needed but not urgent.
Presence of even __________ danger sign indicates that underlying disease is severe
For assessing a general danger sign, a healthcare provider needs to ASK _____ questions and LOOK for ______ observations to observe the child\'s actions.
Which of the following is NOT a danger sign?
Child is not able to drink or breastfeed
Child has had more than one convulsion or prolonged convulsion, or is convulsing now.
A classification in a Yellow row (IMNCI chart) is a classification of very severe disease and needs urgent attention and referral.
Which of the following is NOT true, if a child has a general danger sign?
Complete assessment immediately - the child has a severe problem.
Observe and reassess child after pre-referral treatment
A child who is not able to hold anything down at all has the sign _______________
Not able to drink or breastfeed
What is the dose of Diazepam required to Stop Convulsions?
To make sugar water: Dissolve 4 level teaspoons of sugar (20 grams) in a _______ cup of clean water.
Cough or difficult breathing that lasts for more than 14 days may indicate ______________.
Talha is 6 months old. He has fast breathing if:
Fast breathing or ____________ if present in a child between 2 months to 5 years of age are the clinical signs for Pneumonia.
The child has chest in drawing if the lower chest wall (lower ribs) goes ____ when the child breathes IN.
What is the dose of Amoxicillin DT (250 gm) for children aged 12 months up to 3 years?
The dose for intramuscular antibiotics (urgent referral); Ampicillin _______mg/kg and Gentamicin ________mg/kg
What is the minimum SpO2 saturation level for urgent referral to a health facility?
Standard flow rates for oxygen through nasal prongs or nasal catheters are up to ____ L/min for infants, up to _____ L/min for older children
Following of the vaccines prevent pneumonia infections, EXCEPT:
What are the harmful home remedies for cough?
Cough syrup containing codeine, antihistamines, alcohol, atropine and expectorants.
1- The death of a child with acute diarrhea is usually due to _____________.
2- A child with persistent diarrhea needs Zinc DT for _________ days.
3- The antibiotic prescribed for dysentery is __________ for 3 days.
4- The common cause of dysentery is ______________ bacteria.
5- Which one of the following is a danger sign for severe dehydration?
6- Shaista is restless, but drinks quickly when you give her water. How would you classify her dehydration?
7- Children with diarrhea who come to a health worker with NO ____________ are put on plan A
8- Identify, which one of the following is NOT a rule for home treatment.
9- What is the dose of Zinc DT for home treatment for a child 6 months or older_____________?
10- _____________vaccination is recommended for diarrhea by WHO for children < 5 years.
1- Skin pustules among young infants are the sign of ____________________.
2- The follow-up book_time for sick young infants with diarrhea and pneumonia is ________ days.
3- Persistent vomiting is defined as vomiting following three attempts to feed the infant within ______ minutes, and the infant vomits after each attempt.
4- Which one of the following is NOT a danger sign for some dehydration in young infants
Movement only when stimulated or no movement at all
Skin pinch goes back very slowly.
5- Pre referral treatment for severe Pneumonia or very severe disease in young infant up to 2 months require first dose of an appropriate _________ antibiotic.
6- What is the correct dose to prepare sugar water?
3 level teaspoons of sugar in a 200-ml cup of clean water.
4 level teaspoons of sugar in a 200-ml cup of clean water.
2 level teaspoons of sugar in a 200-ml cup of clean water.
5 level teaspoons of sugar in a 250-ml cup of clean water.
One visit during every month of pregnancy
One visit per month during the first 28 weeks, then two visits per month between 28 weeks and birth
Four visits, with additional visits as needed
One visit per month up to 28 weeks, two visits per month between 28 and 36 weeks, and one visit per week between 36 and 40 weeks
Danger signs of pregnancy include all of the following except:
The position of the fetus should be confirmed:
Components of FANC include all of the following except:
Early detection of complications arising during the pregnancy
Birth preparedness and complication readiness planning
A mother with which of the following blood groups is a candidate for Anti-D immunoglobulin:
From the following list, please indicate which conditions are danger signs of pregnancy:
Are You Sure You Want To Continue?
The presenting symptoms for threatened abortion include:
Heavy vaginal bleeding, dilated cervix, and uterus larger than dates
Light vaginal bleeding, closed cervix, and uterus that corresponds to dates
Heavy vaginal bleeding, dilated cervix, and uterus that corresponds to dates
Light vaginal bleeding, dilated cervix, and uterus smaller than dates
Management of inevitable abortion when the pregnancy is greater than 16 weeks usually involves:
Awaiting spontaneous expulsion of products of conception followed by evacuation of the uterus
Incomplete abortion can be diagnosed according to:
Heavy bleeding, dilated cervix, and partial expulsion of products of conception
The best way to determine uterine size is by:
A history of amenorrhea based on last menstrual period
Assessment of a woman who presents with vaginal bleeding after 28 weeks of pregnancy should:
Which of the following is correct description of a Partograph?
It is a graphic representation of labor progress and the condition of the mother and fetus.
It is a tool to document cervical dilation during labor.
It is a tool to document fetal heart sounds during labor.
Plotting of the Partograph should start when cervix is:
Recording and plotting of fetal heart sounds is mandatory in the first stage of labor at the following interval:
Contractions during labor should be charted for:
Decision-making is important when plotting of cervical dilation is:
Between the alert line and the action line
Which of the following is not observed in Pre-Eclampsia?
Gestational age of more than 20 weeks
The drug of choice for preventing convulsions in severe Pre-Eclampsia and Eclampsia is:
When you assess and take the history of a woman with severe Pre-Eclampsia, what is the most important information you should know about her:
If she has a family history of pre-eclampsia/eclampsia
If she has a severe headache and decreased urine output
The recommended dose of calcium for the prevention of pre-eclampsia in all women is:
The loading dose of magnesium sulfate is given via:
IV over 20 minutes, followed by deep IM injection into each buttock
IV over 5 minutes, followed by deep IM injection into one buttock
IV bolus, followed by deep IM injection into each buttock
The most common cause of PPH is:
Bleeding occurring after 24 hours of childbirth
Bleeding occurring within 24 hours of childbirth
Bleeding occurring within 48 hours of childbirth
Vaginal bleeding of any amount after childbirth
Vaginal bleeding in excess of 300mL after childbirth
Vaginal bleeding in excess of 500mL after childbirth
The proper starting dose of oxytocin for management of PPH in uterine atony is:
10 IU in 1,000 mL of saline at the rate of 60 drops/minute
5 IU in 1,000 mL of Ringer’s lactate at the rate of 60 drops/minute
10 IU stat + 20 IU in 1,000 mL of saline at the rate of 60 drops/minute
Hypovolemic shock due to excessive vaginal bleeding is characterized by
Bimanual compression of the uterus for treatment of PPH due to uterine atony after vaginal birth is recommended as:
The placenta is considered retained if it is not delivered within:
Retained placenta may be caused by:
Wearing sterile gloves is necessary for:
After manual removal of the placenta, monitoring the woman’s vital signs is mandatory for:
Which of the following is not a sign of shock?
Pulse greater than 110 beats per minute
Systolic blood pressure less than 90 mm Hg
Rapid initial assessment for hypovolemic shock does not include:
If a patient is in shock, start rapid infusion as follows:
Management of a patient with shock is the responsibility of:
A patient is said to be stabilized after initial rapid management if:
Puerperal sepsis is an infection of the genital tract:
At any book_time before the 42nd day after birth
At any book_time after the 42nd day after birth
At any book_time between the rupture of membranes or onset of labor and the 42nd day after birth
At any book_time after the 40th day after birth
Prolonged labor of more than 24 hours
More than three vaginal exams during labor
A reddened, wedge-shaped area on the breast is a typical sign of:
Lower abdominal pain and uterine tenderness, together with foul-smelling lochia, are characteristics of:
The treatment of Metritis should include:
IV ampicillin, IV gentamicin, or IV metronidazole
IV ampicillin, IV gentamicin, and IV metronidazole
What is a sign of good attachment at the breast?
The baby’s nose is pressed against the breast
The baby bites down and pulls on the nipple.
Only the tip of breast is in the baby’s mouth.
The baby’s mouth is wide open on the breast.
What should mothers do if they have breast engorgement?
Feed more often or express milk
At 90 minutes after birth, a 2700 gram baby is skin-to-skin with the mother and has a temperature of 36.0 °C. What should you do next?
Give antibiotics and seek advanced care.
This temperature is normal and no special care is needed
Make the room warm and free of drafts and replace any wet clothing.
Place warm stones next to the baby
Babies with what problem might benefit from cup feeding?
Able to swallow but unable to suck effectively
When cup feeding a baby, what is the correct action?
Allow the baby to lick the milk from the cup
Pour small quantities of milk into the baby’s mouth
Place the baby flat on his back
Drip a continuous stream of milk into the mouth
Which of the following would describe convulsions?
Cannot be stopped by holding arms and legs
Occur in response to a loud noise
Occur only when the baby is awake
When should a baby be treated with antibiotics?
If birth weight is less than 2000 grams
When a Danger Sign is present
If the baby appears to be in pain
When should the first dose of an antibiotic be given?
As soon as possible after a Danger Sign has been identified
After all family members have been contacted
At a book_time that is convenient for the health care provider
After the first day following birth, jaundice is severe when it appears on what body area?
How often should a mother express milk for a baby who cannot feed at the breast?
As often as the baby would normally feed (8–12 times per 24 hours)
Once in the morning and once before bed book_time
A 3000 gram baby is unable to suck or swallow during the first 6 hours after birth. How would you classify this baby and what should you do?
The baby is normal, and breastfeeding should be encouraged
The baby has a Danger Sign, and you should seek advanced care
The baby has a feeding problem, and should be cup fed.
The baby will probably die, and no further care should be provided
Which of the following is a sign that a baby is breastfeeding adequately?
Crying within one hour after each feeding
Vigorous sucking that causes nipple pain with each feeding
Remains awake and active after each feeding
You have determined that a baby with a birth weight of 1800 grams needs antibiotics. How much ampicillin (200 mg/mL) should you give?
How long should initial skin-to-skin care be provided by healthy mothers of well babies?
As long as it is convenient for the mother
Only until the baby’s temperature is normal
During the first hour after birth, how often should babies be observed for breathing problems?
Why is it important to begin breastfeeding within the first hour after birth?
It helps babies breastfeed more successfully
It keeps the baby from crying
It keeps babies alert soon after birth
It helps babies breathe more easily
When should a baby be given liquids other than breast milk?
When the baby does not feed at the breast within the first hour after birth
When the mother has engorged breasts
When the baby cries between feedings
What is an early sign that a baby is ready to breast feed?
Crying for a long period of book_time
Breathing rapidly with the mouth open
How fast should a normal baby breathe?
At any rate as long as there is no chest in-drawing
What is the most important reason for weighing all babies soon after birth?
Birth weight may identify babies who need special care
Mother and family members often want to know the birth weight
Birth weight will determine how long a baby will breast feed at each feeding
Birth weight will identify babies who need vitamin K
In what part of the eye should medicine to prevent eye infections be given?
In the corner of the eye only
On the outside of the eye lid
What is the normal temperature range for a healthy baby?
Which babies should be given vitamin K after birth?
Only babies with birth weight >2500 grams
How should a baby be kept warm after skin-to-skin care?
Wrapping in a clean, dry blanket or cloth
How soon after birth can a healthy baby be bathed?
As soon as the baby has a normal temperature
As soon as normal breathing has been established
At least six hours following birth
Which of the following statements correctly describes a well small baby?
Feed by cup, stays warm with skin-to-skin care, has convulsions
Feeds by cup, stays warm with skin-to-skin care, weighs 1600 grams
Breastfeeds poorly, breathes at 100 times per minute, maintains temperature in an incubator
Feeds by cup, weighs 1200 grams, maintains temperature in an incubator
Which of the following is an important step in the care of a small baby?
Teaching the mother to give a bath
Giving the small baby lots of book_time in the sunlight
Preventing infection by washing hands before touching the baby
Weighing the small baby five times a day
Which of the following statements describes preparation for the birth of a small baby?
Identify a skilled helper, provide extra warmth in the area for Delivery, anticipate need to help the baby breathe at birth.
Prepare an area for the baby’s bath, check equipment, review emergency plan.
Wash hands, prepare herbs for babies first feeding.
Anticipate need to help baby breathe at birth, identify a skilled helper, prepare an area for the baby’s bath.
A 1700 gram baby has been placed skin-to-skin with the mother after birth. What other care should be provided in the first 90 minutes after birth?
Showing the baby to the extended family
Feeding the baby with a nasogastric tube
At 90 minutes after birth, an 1800 gram baby is placed skin-to-skin with the mother and has a temperature of 36.7˚ C. What should you do to help maintain the baby’s temperature?
Bathe the baby in warm water.
Assist mother with continuous skin-to-skin care.
Place the baby on an open warmer set for high heat output.

Shortly after birth, a small baby is classified based on the temperature, weight, and physical exam. The baby is 1400 grams, is breathing at 90 breaths per minute, and has a temperature of 35˚C. What should you do?
Put the baby to the breast to assess breastfeeding.
Place a nasogastric tube to administer a feeding.
Arrange a transfer for advanced care.
How many feedings should a small baby receive in a day?
Which of the following techniques can help a mother to support or improve a small baby’s latch?
Wrapping the breasts in tight clothing between feedings
Supporting the head of the baby so he is positioned to take the nipple and surrounding area into an open mouth
Feeding first with a bottle until sucking is strong
What is the skin temperature of a well small baby?
Shortly after birth, the temperature of an 1800 gram baby is 36˚C. After placing the baby skin-to-skin, the baby’s temperature remains the same. Which of the following actions should be taken?
Place the baby in direct sunlight.
Place warm stones around the baby.
Bathe the baby in warm water.
Remove wet diaper and cover the mother and the baby with a blanket.

A 1600 gram baby has been maintaining temperature with continuous skin-to-skin care. The babies will not breastfeed or cup feed and requires nasogastric feeding. What do you advise the mother about skin-to- skin care?
The mother can continue skin-to-skin care even while the baby is receiving nasogastric feedings.
The baby will need to be in an incubator while receiving nasogastric feeding.
The baby will need to be on a radiant warmer while receiving nasogastric feeding.
The mother must stop skin-to-skin care during nasogastric feeding.
When a baby cannot feed directly from the breast after support is provided, what should you advise a mother to do next?
Keep trying to breastfeed the baby.
Express her breast milk to feed to the baby by a safe, alternate feeding method.
Wait until the baby can feed directly from the breast.
When a mother expresses her breast milk, how can it be stored safely?
In a covered container in a cool place for up to 6 hours
In an open container in a shaded area
In an open container in direct sunlight
In a covered container heated in warm water until used
When breastfeeding is not effective, which of the following are safe and recommended alternate feeding methods for a small baby?
Attempt a cup feedings and if not successful, insert a nasogastric tube.
Use a syringe to pour milk directly into the baby’s mouth.
Dip finger or tongue depressor into milk and allow the baby to lick the milk.
Give bottle feedings and insert a nasogastric tube.
Which of the following best describes a 3-day-old 1800 gram baby who needs nasogastric tube feeding?
The baby is breastfeeding 8–12 times per day.
The baby is gaining 15 grams/kilogram per day.
The baby shows feeding readiness cues every 2–4 hours.
The baby takes 5–10 mL by cup per feeding for 4 feedings.
What is the proper length for nasogastric tube insertion?
From the tip of the nose to earlobe to half way between the tip of the breast bone and the umbilicus
From the mouth opening to the nipple to the umbilicus
From the earlobe to the umbilicus
From the earlobe to the umbilicus

Just inserted a nasogastric tube into a small baby who cannot breastfeed or receive cup feedings. Which of the following best describes a method for confirming proper placement of the nasogastric tube?
Measure the tube outside the nose.
Inject 2 mL of air while listening with a stethoscope for the sound of air entering the stomach.
Administer 5 mL of a feeding and then withdraw it back to see if it is mixed with gastric contents.
What should a mother be taught to do before administering a nasogastric feeding?
Wash her hands and reinsert the nasogastric tube.
Wash her hands and confirm placement of the nasogastric tube by checking that the mark on the tube is at the edge of the nose.
Wash her hands and confirm placement of the nasogastric tube by checking that the mark on the tube is at the sternum.
Wash her hands and inject 10 mL of air into the tube.
After initial weight loss, how much weight should a small baby gain each day?
5 grams per kilogram per day on average
15 grams per kilogram per day on average
25 grams per kilogram per day on average
On the day after birth, a 1600 gram baby cannot breastfeed or cup feed, and will be fed every three hours by a nasogastric tube. What volume should be administered for the baby’s first feeding?
A 1600 gram baby is fed by a nasogastric tube. After the initial day of feedings, what is the daily increase in the volume of each feeding?
Which of the following indicates feeding intolerance and the need for advanced care?
In a small baby being fed by an alternative method, how often should breastfeeding readiness be assessed?
At least once every two weeks

A small baby is now 10 days old and has been fed by nasogastric tube e birtshin.c During the first attempt to breast feed, he sucks actively, and swallowing sounds are heard. What should be done next to make the transition to breastfeeding?
top nasogastric feeding immediately, pull out the nasogastric tube, and breastfeed only.
ontinue with nasogastric feeding, while gradually increasing the number of breastfeeding attempts per day.
top nasogastric feeding immediately and breastfeed only throughout the daytime.
ontinue with nasogastric feeding, wait two days, and try breastfeeding again.

A 1600 gram baby has been receiving nasogastric feeding for 10 days and now has started to feed at the breast. Which of the following is an indication that the baby is ready to receive all the feedings by breast?
Waking and crying in between feedings.
Sucking and swallowing audibly for 10 minutes during each feeding
Weight gain of 5 grams per day when no nasogastric feedings are provided
In the first minute after birth, you should
You identify a helper and review the emergency plan
You ask everyone but the mother to leave the area
You prepare equipment only when you need it
You do not need a helper
To prepare the area for delivery
Open all the doors and windows to get fresh air
A clean space for the baby will not be required
Make sure the area is clean, warm, and well-lighted
Which baby can receive routine care after birth?
A baby who is not breathing
A baby who is crying and/or breathing well
Routine care for a healthy baby at birth includes
Drying, removing the wet cloth, and bathing the baby
Drying, removing the wet cloth, and positioning the baby skin-to-skin
Bathing and putting clean clothes on the baby
Drying and wrapping the baby in the wet cloth
When should the umbilical cord be clamped or tied and cut during routine care?
Immediately after the baby is born
A baby is quiet, limp and not breathing at birth. What should you do?
Throw cold water on the face
A baby is born through meconium-stained amniotic fluid. Which statement is TRUE?
Stimulate the baby and then clear the airway
Meconium cannot be inhaled into the lungs
Clear the airway before drying the baby
All babies born through meconium-stained amniotic fluid can receive routine care
What should you do in The Golden Minute SM?
Help a baby breathe if necessary
A newborn baby is quiet, limp and not crying. The baby does not respond to steps to stimulate breathing. What should you do next?
Which of the following statements about ventilation with bag and mask isTRUE?
The mask should cover the eyes
bAir should escape between the mask and face
cSqueeze the bag to produce gentle movement of the chest
dSqueeze the bag to give 80 to 100 breaths per minute
Which of the following signs MUST be monitored in a baby during the first few hours after birth?
A baby\'s chest is not moving with bag and mask ventilation. What should you do?
Reapply the mask to get a better seal
Baby\'s heart rate is 80 per minute
Baby\'s heart rate is 120 per minute and the chest is not moving
Baby\'s heart rate is 120 per minute and the baby is breathing or crying
What should you do to keep the baby warm?
Open all the windows to allow warm air to circulate
Give the baby a bath after birth
Place hot water bottles next to the baby\'s skin
Place the baby skin-to-skin with mother
What should you do to keep the baby clean?
Wash your hands before touching the baby and help mother wash her hands
Reuse the suction device before cleaning
Keep the umbilical cord tightly covered
A newborn baby\'s heart rate should be:
The death of a child with acute diarrhea is usually due to _____________.
The common cause of dysentery is ______________ bacteria
Which one of the following is a danger sign for severe dehydration?
Shaista is restless, but drinks quickly when you give her water. How would you classify her dehydration?
_____________vaccination is recommended for diarrhea by WHO for children less than 5 years
A child with persistent diarrhea needs Zinc DT for _________ days.
The antibiotic prescribed for dysentery is __________ for 3 days.
Children with diarrhea who come to a health worker with NO ____________ are put on plan A
Identify, which one of the following is NOT a rule for home treatment.
What is the dose of Zinc DT for home treatment for a child 6 months or older_____________?
½ tablet per day for 12 days
Skin pustules among young infants are the sign of ____________________.
Which one of the following is NOT a danger sign for some dehydration in young infants
Movement only when stimulated or no movement at all
Skin pinch goes back very slowly
The follow-up book_time for sick young infants with diarrhea and pneumonia is ________ days.
Persistent vomiting is defined as vomiting following three attempts to feed the infant within ______ minutes, and the infant vomits after each attempt.
Pre referral treatment for severe Pneumonia or very severe disease in young infant up to 2 months require first dose of an appropriate _________ antibiotic
What is the correct dose to prepare sugar water?
3 level teaspoons of sugar in a 200-ml cup of clean water.
4 level teaspoons of sugar in a 200-ml cup of clean water.
2 level teaspoons of sugar in a 200-ml cup of clean water.
5 level teaspoons of sugar in a 250-ml cup of clean water.
